displayed_text: Patient: Uh-huh. Uh-huh. Doctor: Three eighty five, no matter where you are in your day, is too high. Patient: Yes. Yeah. Family Member: It will make you feel sick. Doctor: It’ll make you feel sick. Family Member: And tired. Doctor: Yeah. Especially now, I’m not even doing a thing to poison you, you should feel better. Doctor: Um hum. So is that the highest? Patient: So absolutely. Absolutely. I don’t, I don’t get readings like that. Doctor: Okay. Patient: You know? It can be in the two twenties. You know? Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: No, we got one last uh two weeks. Doctor: So, we’ll figure out when your next one is and you’ll come back for that for sure Patient: Okay. Doctor: and then just know you can call anytime and come back in between. Patient: Okay. Alright. Doctor: And then the chemo we’ll just push back but just know it’s around. Patient: That’s right. Doctor: But who knows what will get developed in the meantime. Patient: Exactly, okay, alright. Doctor: Good, yeah. Patient: Um, about how long do you think this will take for them to… Doctor: To get going?

Family Member: Yes. Doctor: to just you may want use that one-eight hundred number. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: It’s easier. It takes away the fact of you having to follow the instructions. Family Member: All right. Doctor: And that is on my card if you really want to use that. Family Member: I have that, yeah. Doctor: Do it yourself, but otherwise, if you just tell the operator then at eight hundred to page what - Patient: Give me your Christmas present. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Okay (chuckles) Patient: No, there you go.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: The new one and then the OxyContin and then uh your Percocet. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now what’s going on with your Zometa and everything? That’s XGEVA is B___ doing that? Patient: Yeah, yes they are, yes they are. Doctor: Alright. Patient: Because you gave the thing last time on on on my uh calcium. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: They highered my calcium level now. Doctor: Let’s see what is this guys’ intake? Yeah it was too low last time.

Patient: and something like that too, but nothing that I’ve had right now and I, I, I I’m not consistent with it. Doctor: Sure. Patient: It’s just something that we’ve tried – Doctor: Right. Patient: - been recommended that we try and I think we brought it up but… Doctor: Yeah. You know cancer is cancer, it’s got its own set of pain. Patient: Well and… Doctor: Here’s the thing you got to take the medication. Patient: You want me to start to take a look at the Norco again or? Doctor: I think you should and just don’t let it get out of control you know, like I’d rather you take it occasionally or all the time if you need to. There’s no right or wrong on that. Family Member: It’s not that bad. Patient: I’m not that bad but there is a lot of inconsistency though.

Patient: He might have been a Norman. Doctor: He might have been! Patient: Which would be worse than anything. Doctor: Maybe they were, yeah. I don’t know. No, I think, that’s French, right? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: No, I don’t have any French. Doctor: I had some Spanish-Portuguese, maybe Doctor: One of my grand, great-grandmothers had a little thing on the side. I don’t know. Doctor: Yeah, the joke is uh – Patient: He used to say that all the time, yeah. Doctor: Mommy’s baby, daddy’s maybe. Is that what I’ve heard? (Laughs) Family Member: It’s twenty-three and me --- Doctor: One of them tells you like how much Neanderthal you have. Ancestry didn’t tell you that.

Patient: -- of this is what the scan report is gonna read which I’m gonna give you right now. So this – but the same areas were the lower back and the left hip, the hip bones, so those are the two main areas. Family Member: And the rib or not the rib? Doctor: The ribs are still there and we are following it. It’s in the left side on the sixth rib. Yeah I mean that also was there before Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: and that stayed about the same. Family Member: But the increased uptake is in the lower back and the left hip? Patient: Previously we were under the impression that the scans were the good news that they haven’t changed. Doctor: I think that is still true. Okay, so my assessment of these scans are they are stable. Okay. Patient: Uh but the PSA which had been going down turned around last month to point four from one point one but then now it’s at one point four doesn’t sound good. Doctor: No. So obviously… Patient: So am I going off the Xtandi or what? Doctor: Well so we have a few choices okay. One is do we add another medication, because typically people who are sort of resistant to Xtandi. There are a couple of pathways of resistance that we know about now. Okay. One of which is something we called BET1 overexpression. B-E-T okay and you’ll get paperwork on this but. So that pathway there is a BET1 inhibitor that we are testing right now.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.4 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::4 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::strongly agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Disabled: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Disabled

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Then they mail it to your house Patient: Okay. Doctor: and then when you get it you take four pills a day. Patient: Mm, Hmm. Doctor: If you can, you just call us, call K__ or W__ and go hey we got the medicine Patient: Right. Doctor: that way I know when you started. When you’ve been on it for two or three weeks, you come back to see me and we’ll make sure you’re doing okay. Patient: When I’m doing okay. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So now okay you know what my next question is… Doctor: Yeah. Patient: You know I got that motorcycle.

Patient: If the PSA is that reliable in terms of – Doctor: Ehhh, it’s reliable enough. I don’t know, it’s not unbelievably reliable, but Patient: But, if – Doctor: Rather than, you know, trying to give you a CAT scan every month. Patient: It’s, it’s, it’s unlikely that the PSA is going to go up if things are okay. Doctor: Yes. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: That’s a reasonable ---- Family Member: But it wouldn’t stay down if things weren’t okay --- if you were getting worse, either. I mean, is there a false – Doctor: I mean, occasionally we have a patient where all the disease is getting better, and then one spot starts to grow. That’s where, that would be the one place we kind of fall through the cracks. But, usually, - the PSA represents the sum of all of the cancers in your body are contributing to it. So, usually, when it’s going down, we sort of think that the sum is going down. And, when it’s going up, we think that it’s starting to be resistant. Um. Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Yeah, really, yeah. Doctor: You had three others or you know things pop up. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Or the bone disease gets worse—whatever. So I think we need a global, generalized control first – Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: - and then we can pick up whatever if that mass is still left in. Patient: There’s uh, okay, is there any other; that was a surprise that it was larger, or that it was even there…there was a marker. Doctor: I know, yeah, the measurement totally did not indicate that. Patient: And why- Doctor: That was a shock. No, I agree with you. Patient: and that’s why – I don’t – that’s what I was trying to get at. It wasn’t there. Doctor: Yes, the reading was completely different from what actually was; you know that’s the problem, that the person reading is not the one doing the CRYO, in this case. Family Member: Right.

Healthcare Professional: Yep, she just has to sign these first. So… Patient: Okay. Healthcare Professional: They won't take them without her signature. Doctor: I’m just a - I’m just wondering, how long did we wait? We waited two weeks now? Healthcare Professional: It was two weeks from-- Doctor: Two weeks from his last uh, when he was last due? Healthcare Professional: Yeah Doctor: Okay. So then I- for now I'm going to stay with the same dose. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I think the next step before this tearing and everything, and we are getting up there in number of cycles you've gotten, Patient: Correct. Doctor: we may need to consider cutting back on the dose or--

Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: you know and then that’s the information that says okay, what do we do next? Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know say I don’t like any of those trials that (names person) Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Yeah, well I’m in favor of the trials. Family Member: There are a lot more side effects with the trials. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I’m not sure there’s more side effects; it’s just sort of we just have to put them out there, talk about them more. Patient: Yes. Doctor: You know chemotherapy has its own set of side effects Patient: Right. Doctor: But we have what the known benefits potentially are, whereas the clinical trials—we don’t know the benefits.

Patient: What kind of breathing machine? Doctor: Uh. A ventilator. On TV. Those are television. Your body’s gotten so sick that if I get you to wake up, you still have the bad cancer. Patient: Oh. Doctor: Okay? So, I also, I mean, I’m not so sure we should be pounding on your chest. Uh, you should be thinking about how far will we go even if it looks bad. (Pause) Patient: No. See, my dad died from prostate cancer in nineteen eighty six. He hadn’t -- didn’t have much treatment at all. Uh. Family Member: He waited, he waited to have severe symptoms. Then he went and then (they’s found) Patient: So, um, you know, I’m concerned for my son. My brother. Uh. He might have something too. I mean, if I try somethin’, it will help ‘em. Doctor: Yeah. I mean, so this may not help you, but it may help us learn how to treat other men in the future. Uh. So, that is, you know, just you being a good citizen and helping that out and a hero, but that – you have to feel comfortable with that, you know, ‘cuz it could help. It may not help. If it does help, it may help others. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um. And yet it’s your time. It’s your coming in here. Some of it’s your expense. You know, this drug enzalutamide, I don’t know what you were paying when you were on it before. Uh. It’s pretty expensive. It’s about ten thousand bucks a month. Um. And again, you would be taking it, even though we don’t think it’s gonna work ‘cuz -- because we think that it may make the immune therapy work better. So, we have to have people on it. Their PSA’s gonna be rising. Their ARV seven still has to be positive. (Laughs) Patient: Okay. I didn’t pay much for the Xtandi before. Uh, some kind of study from manufacturers – Doctor: Oh, so you had a study, or they had a, uh, a program that sort of reduced your cost?

Family Member: Well you couldn’t just do that as, like say you try it on those two guys, don’t you just try that with B__, knowing that there is still Germany, but um-? Doctor: Possibly. I have to figure how to get the immune therapy because it’s not an improved thing. Patient: Oh. Doctor: So there’s just some hoops to jump through. Family Member: Well, we’re kind of there now. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Like we really want to be treating this aggressively. Doctor: Well, I think if I was going to choose between those two things, and I had the means to choose between the two, I would choose the PSMA. Patient: Yes, I know. Doctor: Yeah. I mean this is really just antidotal for me for two patients. They’ve got other things in between that could have nothing to do with testosterone. We’re, we’re trying to make as much, we’ve got somebody interested in a small trial to test the idea, but I, I really, I wouldn’t be that confident. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Like you said, geez, which has the better chance? Family Member: No. I would still be doing the Germany thing, I just-
